G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the action arises under Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Norfolk Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the cause of action arose in the County of Norfolk, where Defendant transacts business and where Plaintiff’s injury occurred.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of Sunny Bistro, owed a duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, to remedy hazards of which it knew or should have known, and to warn invitees of any danger which it could not immediately correct.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurring opinion focused on criticizing the continued significance of the trespasser category after Mounsey abolished the invitee/licensee distinction. It does not articulate or apply the specific duty rule for owners/occupiers toward lawful visitors (invitees) regarding maintaining safe premises, remedying known hazards, or warning of dangers. While the main Mounsey decision is foundational for Massachusetts premises-liability duties, this particular excerpt does not itself state or support the detailed duty proposition cited for Sunny Bistro.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant, as the owner and operator of Sunny Bistro, owed a duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, to remedy hazards of which it knew or should have known, and to warn invitees of any danger which it could not immediately correct.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the modern Massachusetts premises‑liability rule for lawful visitors, tracking the elements in the proposition: a duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, to repair or remove dangerous conditions the owner knows or should know about, and to warn of dangers not known or obvious. Although the facts involve a mall parking lot rather than a restaurant, the duty is stated generally for all property owners and thus applies to an owner‑operator like Sunny Bistro.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….” This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known. See Kelley v. Goldberg, 288 Mass. 79, 81 (1934).

Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.raw_text: Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sch., Inc., 408 Mass. 393, 404 (1990)
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.proposition: Defendant’s employees acted within the scope of their employment, making Defendant vicariously liable under the doctrine of respondeat superior.
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.case_name: Worcester Insurance v. Fells Acres Day School, Inc.
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.support_reasoning: The court expressly holds that the employees’ sexual assaults were not within the scope of their employment and therefore did not give rise to traditional respondeat superior liability for Fells Acres. The opinion rejects vicarious liability both under the standard scope-of-employment test and under any proposed expansion akin to common-carrier liability. Thus, the case is authority against, not for, the proposition that the defendant is vicariously liable because its employees acted within the scope of employment.
Worcester Ins. Co. v. Fells Acres Day Sc.relevant_excerpt: “On this issue, the parties have directed their arguments not at the question of insurance coverage, but at the question whether there can be any vicarious liability claim or claims under the stipulated facts… Under this standard, the conduct alleged here does not trigger vicarious liability… Moreover, these acts obviously were not ‘of the kind [the employees were] employed to perform,’ nor were they ‘motivated, at least in part, by a purpose to serve the employer.’… On the basis of the stipulated facts, then, Fells Acres is not vicariously liable for the assaults and batteries.”

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167‑68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the duty of ordinary care owed to business invitees under Massachusetts common law of premises liability.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the duty owed by one who controls business premises to patrons and cites prior premises-liability cases, articulating the Massachusetts common-law standard of ordinary (due) care toward business invitees. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on these facts and orders judgment for the defendant, its description of the duty itself directly supports the general proposition about the duty of ordinary care owed to business invitees under Massachusetts premises liability law.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know.”

Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.raw_text: Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass. 560, 563 (1955)
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the duty of ordinary care owed to business invitees under Massachusetts common law of premises liability.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.support_reasoning: The court expressly applies Massachusetts premises liability principles to a business visitor, framing the defendant’s obligation as a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe and analyzing whether the defendant breached that duty by failing to discover and remove the ice cream. The opinion reaffirms that business owners owe invitees a duty of ordinary care—not that they are insurers—and holds that the evidence was sufficient for a jury to find a negligent failure to meet that duty. This directly supports the stated proposition about breach of the duty of ordinary care to business invitees under Massachusetts law.
Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 332 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We said in White v. Mugar, 280 Mass. 73, at page 75, ‘The defendant owed to customers a duty to keep the premises reasonably safe for their use. He, however, is not an insurer of safety. Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action.’ … We think that it could be found, however, that the presence of this ice cream … constituted an appreciable danger to customers.”

Ventura v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 438 M.raw_text: Ventura v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 438 Mass. 527, 529‑30 (2003)
Ventura v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 438 M.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes a breach of the duty of ordinary care owed to business invitees under Massachusetts common law of premises liability.
Ventura v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 438 M.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns standards for probable cause hearings and evidentiary issues in sexually dangerous person civil commitment proceedings under G.L. c. 123A. It does not involve premises liability, business invitees, or the duty of ordinary care under Massachusetts tort law. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that a defendant’s conduct breached the duty of ordinary care owed to business invitees in a premises-liability context.
Ventura v. Cumberland Farms, Inc., 438 M.relevant_excerpt: The Commonwealth appeals from a Superior Court judge’s finding of no probable cause to believe that Christopher J. Reese was a sexually dangerous person as defined in G. L. c. 123A, § 1. The judge based his finding of no probable cause on subsidiary findings that the testimony of the Commonwealth’s expert that Reese (1) was a pedophile; (2) suffered from a “personality disorder”; and (3) was likely to commit additional sexual offenses if not confined to a secure facility, was not credible.

DeSarno v. Worcester, 360 Mass. 127, 130.proposition: The dangerous condition existed for such a time that Defendant, exercising reasonable care, should have discovered and removed it.

Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Thurlow v. Shaw’s Supermarkets, Inc., 49 Mass. App. Ct. 175, 177‑78 (2000)
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: The dangerous condition existed for such a time that Defendant, exercising reasonable care, should have discovered and removed it.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses constructive notice and upholds a finding that water from melting/spilled ice around a fish display had been present long enough that Shaw’s, exercising reasonable care, should have discovered and remedied it. The court affirms the trial judge’s inference, based on the elapsed time since the last sweep and the obvious nature of the melting, that someone at Shaw’s reasonably should have been aware of the water for almost two hours. This directly supports the proposition about a dangerous condition existing long enough to impose a duty to discover and remove it.
Thurlow v. Shaw\u2019s Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Liability will only attach if the plaintiff establishes by a preponderance of the evidence that the foreign substance was there long enough that the defendant’s employees should have seen it and cleaned it up… The judge found that the last sweep of the floor was at 10 p.m., or about one and three-quarters hours before the accident took place… we are not prepared to say that the judge’s finding that ‘someone at Shaw’s reasonably should have been aware of this amount of water on the floor in front of the fish display case [for almost two hours]’ is plainly wrong.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant failed to maintain its premises in a condition reasonably safe for invitees, in violation of its duty as articulated in G.L. c. 231, § 85, and related common law principles.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6F.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover the full measure of damages permitted under Massachusetts tort law, including G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6F, which permit interest and costs in actions for personal injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award prejudgment and postjudgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
